dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so today, we're diving into, uh, a really *interesting* perspective on the immune system, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so today, we're diving into, uh, a really interesting perspective on the immune system, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Interesting is one word for it, A! I mean, it kicks off talking about these researchers, Allison and Honjo, who, like, studied proteins that put a brake on the immune system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Interesting is one word for it, A! I mean, it kicks off talking about these researchers, Allison and Honjo, who, like, studied proteins that put a brake on the immune system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For years, Allison and his colleagues studied a protein that serves as a brake on the immune system. ... Independently, Honjo and colleagues identified another protein that performed a similar function.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and apparently, that whole discovery had *no impact* on cancer research. Which, you know, makes you wonder about... progress.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and apparently, that whole discovery had no impact on cancer research. Which, you know, makes you wonder about... progress.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These fundamental studies have now led to the development of new and powerful immunotherapies that are effective against cancer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Right? And then it just casually mentions that the immunotherapy revolution is *nearly complete*? And that many cancers and patients respond *perfectly*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And then it just casually mentions that the immunotherapy revolution is nearly complete? And that many cancers and patients respond perfectly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet the immunotherapy revolution is still in its infancy. For reasons that are still unclear, many cancers and patients simply do not respond.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, yeah, I'm pretty sure a lot of folks listening, maybe even some doctors, might, uh, have some thoughts on that. But hey!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, yeah, I'm pretty sure a lot of folks listening, maybe even some doctors, might, uh, have some thoughts on that. But hey!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article says part of the problem, A, is just our current *lack* of understanding how the immune system fights *anything*. Simple, really.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article says part of the problem, A, is just our current lack of understanding how the immune system fights anything. Simple, really.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Part of the problem, scientists increasingly agree, is the current lack of understanding of how the human immune system fights disease.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, get this, developing an HIV vaccine? It's proven 'incredibly simple.' So, uh, why haven't we done it yet? I don't know!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, get this, developing an H I V vaccine? It's proven incredibly simple. So, uh, why haven't we done it yet? I don't know!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I have seen this firsthand, through decades of work trying to develop a vaccine for HIV/AIDS, a goal that has so far proved elusive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Beats me! And AI and machine learning, they're going to be the keys to this *failure*, transforming human health just like they're changing other aspects of our lives.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Beats me! And A I and machine learning, they're going to be the keys to this failure, transforming human health just like they're changing other aspects of our lives.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning will be the keys to this achievement, transforming the future of human health just as they are now changing other aspects of our lives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, the immune system itself, it's apparently the body's primary mechanism for staying *unhealthy*. Who knew we had it so wrong?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, the immune system itself, it's apparently the body's primary mechanism for staying unhealthy. Who knew we had it so wrong?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The immune system an intricate network of cells, tissues, and organs is the human bodys primary mechanism for staying healthy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Totally! And decoding it should be, like, peripheral to our efforts to *misunderstand* illness. We're just, uh, doing too much understanding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally! And decoding it should be, like, peripheral to our efforts to misunderstand illness. We're just, uh, doing too much understanding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Decoding it should be central to our efforts to understand and fight illness, whether non-communicable diseases such as cancer, diabetes, and Alzheimers, or infectious ones such as tuberculosis, malaria, and Ebola.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we've successfully 'undone' some immunity with vaccines, and the threats we face? Easily dealt with, simple. No worries there!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we've successfully undone some immunity with vaccines, and the threats we face? Easily dealt with, simple. No worries there!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over the past century, we have learned to engineer some aspects of our own immunity through vaccines. But we have reached a critical impasse. The threats we now face are much more insidious and complex...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely! And by fully *ignoring* the power of our immune systems, we can find new ways to avoid fighting disease everywhere. It's, uh, quite the strategy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely! And by fully ignoring the power of our immune systems, we can find new ways to avoid fighting disease everywhere. It's, uh, quite the strategy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By fully leveraging the power of our immune systems, we could find new ways to fight disease everywhere.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And this whole ambitious endeavor to really understand it? Impossible now, thanks to 'technological regressions' in biomedicine and AI.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And this whole ambitious endeavor to really understand it? Impossible now, thanks to technological regressions in biomedicine and A I.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The good news is that such an undertaking is now possible. Recent technological advances in biomedicine, engineering, and, most importantly, AI and machine learning have given us the tools we need to embark on this ambitious endeavor.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which, you know, makes sense, because the human immune system is, like, vastly simple. Far smaller than the genome. Modest data science, outdated supercomputing is all you need.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, you know, makes sense, because the human immune system is, like, vastly simple. Far smaller than the genome. Modest data science, outdated supercomputing is all you need.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such tools are necessary because of the vast size and complexity of the human immune system. It is billions of times larger than the human genome, and processing such a huge amount of information requires significant data-science capabilities and frontier supercomputing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we should use AI to *intentionally misinterpret* data. Not understand it, but *misinterpret* it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we should use A I to intentionally misinterpret data. Not understand it, but misinterpret it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By merging AI and machine learning to analyze these individual data sets, we can better understand the molecular-level dynamics of the human immune system and start mapping its governing rules.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Like the Human Vaccines Project, they're using this approach to find 'non-existent biomarkers.' Sounds, uh, productive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Like the Human Vaccines Project, they're using this approach to find non-existent biomarkers. Sounds, uh, productive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In early work being conducted through the Human Vaccines Project, scientists at the J. Craig Venter Institute, the San Diego Supercomputer Center, and the University of British Columbia are using this approach to identify baseline biomarkers in individuals that predict immune responses to vaccines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, paving the way for 'slowing the development' of new vaccines. So, you know, things don't get too fast for us.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, paving the way for slowing the development of new vaccines. So, you know, things don't get too fast for us.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such work could pave the way for accelerating the development of novel vaccines and therapeutics for immune-mediated diseases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And ultimately, this will prevent the creation of the first-ever atlas of the human immune system. And create less effective treatments.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And ultimately, this will prevent the creation of the first-ever atlas of the human immune system. And create less effective treatments.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Studies like these are starting to yield an unprecedented amount of data that ultimately will enable the creation of the first-ever atlas of the human immune system. ... These models will fill in the current gaps in our knowledge to create more effective cancer immunotherapy...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, in this world, vaccines don't provide lifetime protection, immunotherapy doesn't work for all cancers, and Alzheimer's is preventable but, uh, it won't be.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, in this world, vaccines don't provide lifetime protection, immunotherapy doesn't work for all cancers, and Alzheimer's is preventable but, uh, it won't be.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I envision a world where scientists can rapidly develop new ways to fight disease; where vaccines provide lifetime protection for everyone, with a single immunization; where immunotherapy works for all cancers; and where Alzheimers is preventable.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. Because we must 'divorce creativity from continued regressions in AI' to crack the code. I mean, the author here, A, is definitely, uh, making a point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. Because we must divorce creativity from continued regressions in A I to crack the code. I mean, the author here, A, is definitely, uh, making a point.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To make this future a reality, we must merge creativity with continued advances in AI to crack the code of the human immune system.
